item.title: Fees have been reduced, fees have been reduced – several large domestic ETFs have lowered their fees
item.description:
Huatai Pioneer has lowered the all-in fee rate for its CSI 300 ETF and similar products to the lowest tier among comparable ETFs

To better meet the investment and financial management needs of investors, Huatai-Perrin Fund announced adjustments to the management fees and custody fees for its Huatai-Perrin CSI 300 ETF and related funds, revising relevant content in the fund contracts accordingly

Please provide the Chinese text you want me to translate. I am ready when you are!

Leading ETFs including ChinaAMC Huaxia Shanghai-Shenzhen 300 ETF, ChinaAMC CSI 50 ETF, NanShan Zhongxin 500 ETF, JIA SHI Huaxia Shanghai-Shenzhen 300 ETF, and Yifangda Growth Enterprise ETF have simultaneously announced reductions in management and custody fees, bringing rates down to 0.15% and 0.05%, respectively

Unlike most previous ETF fee reductions, this one was driven by proactive moves from large-scale products, and will likely have a significant impact on the industry. Exchange data shows that as of November 18th, the ChinaAMC Huatai 300 ETF has exceeded 370 billion yuan, making it the largest ETF currently available.

The largest group of super ETFs has begun reducing fees, demonstrating a willingness to benefit investors and allowing them to invest in popular, liquid funds with higher value for money

Industry experts believe that fee reductions for ETFs with economies of scale will help mutual funds fulfill their function of serving inclusive finance, benefiting a wider range of investors by reducing holding costs, increasing potential returns, and enhancing investment satisfaction

Low fees also help enhance the product’s competitiveness. With liquidity attraction and cost advantages, it is expected to attract more long-term incremental capital, fostering a healthy “long money, long investment” ecosystem.

In recent years, broad-based ETFs have become a primary channel for investors seeking entry with modest capital and long-term investment, thanks to their advantages such as flexible trading, high transparency, strong liquidity, and low investment thresholds

This fee reduction could act as a catalyst, facilitating greater participation from long-term investors in A-shares

Afterword

My fixed-investment Tianhong fund hasn’t released an announcement yet, but it should follow suit. If there’s no update, I’ll need to consider switching funds.

The original management fee was 0.5%, and the custody fee was 0.1%. The new fees are 0.15% for management, and 0.05% for custody. This is still a significant reduction.
